5.text: Parliament sits on a sessional basis and each session there is a Queen's speech

legislative programme. The first thing that
normally happens is there might have been a draft

19.text:
bill published that everybody can have a
look at even before it comes into the

23.text:
chamber to be debated. Once they appear
on the order paper

26.text: the Clerk will read out the title of the bill. It's the formal first reading of a bill

32.text: and that starts the whole process off. The next thing that

35.text: happens is a debate in parliament

38.text: and it is called a second reading debate and what that really means is

42.text: in principle what do we think this bill is about. Members from both sides

49.text:
will indicate what they like about it what
they don't like about it.

52.text:
At end of that process it will then go to to a
Committee

69.text: Basically,  it's just like a project team

72.text:
of MPs from across all the different
parties. They go away and they literally

76.text: go through the the bill line-by-line, it's a bit like editing a book.

83.text:
Parliament and the chamber looks at this
revised bill and then have that final

87.text:
debate. At that stage the Commons has
really had it's say it goes over to the House

94.text:
pretty much the same process they then
throw it back to the Commons, we debate that

102.text:
we reach a conclusion about what it
should end up looking like.
